I. 

THE PROPOSAL 

1. 
I  submit  for  your  approval  the  following  report  and  recommendation  on  a  proposed 
senior  loan  of  $50,000,000  to  TBC  Bank  (TBC)  for  Promoting  Financial  Sector  Growth  and 
Service Diversity in Georgia.1 
 

II. 

THE FINANCIAL INTERMEDIARY 

 
A. 

Investment Identification and Description  

2. 
After  the  recession  that  followed  the  financial  crisis  and  the  conflict  with  the  Russian 
Federation in 2008, Georgia witnessed a strong rebound with real economic growth exceeding 
6%  per  annum  in  2010  and  2011.  However,  the  recession  highlighted  the  adverse  impact  on 
incomes  and  poverty,  as  well  as  the  importance  of  robust  financial  systems  in  a  volatile 
economic  environment.  Although  Georgia  is  a  lower  middle-income  country,  poverty  remains 
high at 25% as of 2010 and in rural areas the incidence of poverty may be as high as 60%.2 
 
Exposure  to  the  macroeconomic  shocks  and  financial  crises  undermined  public 
3. 
confidence in Georgia’s banking sector since the collapse of the Soviet Union. Private credit to 
gross  domestic  product  (GDP)  averaged  31%  (2008–2010),  indicating  a  depth  of  financial 
intermediation far below other middle-income peers.3 Access to financial services is moderate in 
Georgia,  but  highly  concentrated  in  the  capital  Tbilisi,  where  78%  of  bank  lending  is  being 
extended.  Georgia’s  regions,4 which  account  for  about  half  the  population,  lag  far  behind  the 
capital  in  accessing  finance,  receiving  only  22%  of  bank  lending. 5 Compared  with  emerging 
markets  in  Eastern  Europe  the  efficiency  and  stability  of  financial  intermediation  are  low,  as 
witnessed by high lending–deposit rate spreads and high defaults in 2008 and 2009. Supporting 
outreach of financial services to the regions and overall stability of the financial sector will have 
major  qualitative  impacts  on  the  economy  and  people,  by  stimulating  rural  income  and 
employment, and supporting critical risk diversification in a volatile macroeconomic environment. 
 
4. 
Although  rural  economic  activity  contributes  only  17%  to  GDP,  it  supports  half  of  the 
population and 65% of employment, of which farms employ 53% and nonfarm enterprises 12% 
(footnote  2). The quality  of growth is  particularly significant  in  rural  areas,  as  it  provides major 
benefits  for  low-income  families  and  stimulates  demand  for  goods  and  services  produced  by 
micro,  small,  and  medium  sized  enterprises  (MSMEs), 6  which  represent  the  bulk  of  rural 
activities.  The  government  has  recognized  that  its  liberal  economic  policies  have  led  to  a 
concentration of activity in the capital, leaving rural areas behind. Stimulating economic activity 
and income generation in the regions has become a government priority, and it is pursuing rural 
investments in infrastructure, agriculture, and agribusiness.7 An increase in international tourism 
points to the potential for additional income and employment opportunities in this sector. 
 
MSMEs in Georgia are a critical contributor to income and employment, with 42% of the 
5. 
labor  force  being  employed  by  small  and  medium-sized  enterprises  (SMEs),  and  many  more

lacked  access  to  finance  because  of  traditional  security-based  lending  processes  that  ignore 
their information availability.8 The senior loan to TBC, Georgia’s second largest bank in terms of 
assets  (GEL3.6  billion  as  of  30  June  2012),  aims  to  support  inclusive  financial  growth  and 
deepen  access  to  finance,  by  extending  funding  to  TBC  for  onlending  to  MSMEs  operating 
exclusively in rural regions outside the capital and supporting TBC as a systemically important 
bank.9 This  is  consistent  with  the  effort  of  the  National  Bank  of  Georgia  (NBG)  to  promote 
financial stability and access to finance.  
 
6. 
In  April  2012,  the  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  entered  into  discussions  with  TBC 
senior management and designed a loan targeted to support MSMEs in Georgia’s rural regions. 
TBC  is  considered  a  good  candidate  for  ADB  funding,  given  its  recent  acquisition  of  Bank 
Constanta,10 and its rural staffing and branch expansion plans. This gives TBC a strong regional 
platform  to  target  and  service  MSMEs  operating  outside  the  capital.  TBC  also  supports  high 
prudential  standards  for  Georgia’s  banking  industry,  and  the  implementation  within  TBC  of 
enhanced systems of governance, capital, and risk management consistent with the introduction 
of  Basel  II  and  Basel  III  regulatory  frameworks.  TBC’s  substantial  improvements  in  its 
governance  and  financial  performance  since  2009  have  been  recognized  internationally,  as 
evidenced  through  credit  rating  upgrades  to  B1  by  Moody’s  and  BB–  by  Fitch  in  June  2012. 
TBC also received Euromoney awards in 2011 and 2012 as the best bank in Georgia. 
 
B. 

Business Overview and Strategy 

7. 
TBC is the second largest bank in Georgia, and is systemically important with a market 
share of 28% of loans and 32% of deposits at 30 September 2012. It has a strong franchise with 
corporate,  SME,  and  retail  clients.  Its  unique  strength  lies  in  its  business  sophistication  and 
outreach  through  cost-effective  distribution  channels.  TBC  plans  to  diversify  its  portfolio  by 
expanding  its  loan  book  in  the  regions,  thereby  reducing  the  concentration  risk  to  large  single 
and group borrowers. The acquisition of Bank Constanta has helped TBC to obtain a stronger 
rural  footprint  through  Bank  Constanta’s  extensive  regional  branch  network  of  44  branches, 
increasing  TBC’s  branches  to  101  as  of  mid-November  2012.  Moreover,  TBC  plans  to 
strengthen  services  to  MSMEs  through  dedicated  regional  branch  units,  and  product  cross-
selling to small and rural enterprises through Bank Constanta and TBC channels. 
 
8. 
In October  2012, TBC  revised  its  business  targets  based  on  the  anticipated  slowing of 
the  Georgian  economy  and  that  of  its  trading  partners,  reflecting  a  more  moderate  growth 
trajectory.  TBC  expects  its  annual  business  growth  to  remain  above  market  growth.  Given  its 
new  focus  on  expanding  outside  Tbilisi,  TBC  projects  its  regional  GLP  to  grow  above  its 
average growth. 
 
9. 
TBC’s diversification is closely associated with its efforts to establish an internal capital 
adequacy  assessment  process  (ICAAP) 11  to  enhance  its  solvency  management  and  risk 
management  through  enhanced  stress  testing  and  forecasting  capabilities  in  accordance  with

C. 

Ownership, Management, and Governance 

10. 
Ownership.  TBC  was  established  in  1992  by  Georgian  entrepreneurs,  M.  Khazaradze 
and  B.  Japaridze,  which  own  27.74%  of  shares.  Since  2001,  international  financial  institutions 
(IFIs) have significant shareholdings. In November 2012 IFIs hold 54.15% of issued shares: the 
International  Finance  Corporation  (19.80%),  the  European  Bank  for  Reconstruction  and 
Development  (19.80%),  German  development  cooperation  through  DEG  (11.32%),  and  the 
Development  Finance  Company  of  the  Netherlands  (FMO)  (3.23%).  Other  shareholders  are 
JP Morgan  (5.34%),  Ashmore  (4.52%),  TBC  management,  and  individuals  who  hold  8.25%  of 
the shares. 
 
11.  Management.  The  management  board  is  composed  of  seven  senior  executives 
including  the  chief  executive  officer,  chief  operating  officer,  chief  financial  officer,  chief  risk 
officer, and three business heads. All have professional backgrounds and most have been with 
TBC for more than 10 years. The chief financial officer and the head of corporate finance have 
international banking experience. With three of the seven management board members, women 
are  well  represented.  The  management  board  sets  TBC’s  strategic  targets,  and  prepares  risk 
limits  and  credit  policies  for  approval  by  the  supervisory  board.  The  management  board 
members are experienced bankers who are well qualified to lead TBC. 
 
12. 
Governance.  TBC  is  governed  by  a  two-tier  board  structure  consisting  of  the 
supervisory  board  and  the  management  board.  The  supervisory  board  is  responsible  for 
overseeing  the  implementation  of  key  policies,  approving  strategic  and  business  targets,  and 
appointing  management  and  monitoring  their  performance.  IFI  shareholders  nominate  four  of 
the  seven  supervisory  board  members,  who  are  currently  all  senior  professionals  with 
international  banking  experience.  The  other  three  supervisory  board  members,  including  the 
chairperson,  are  well-known  Georgian  entrepreneurs.  There  are  currently  no  independent 
directors, and the incumbent chairperson, M. Khazaradze, has held the position for 20 years. 
 
13. 
In anticipation of the introduction of Basel II, TBC is preparing to establish a new credit 
risk  committee  under  the  supervisory  board  in  2013.  The  shareholders  have  also  determined 
that the supervisory  board  will  be  supported  by  (i)  a new  remuneration  committee responsible 
for management  board  remuneration  policies,  (ii)  a new  nomination  committee responsible for 
management  board  appointments,  and  (iii)  an  enhanced  audit  committee  that  will  cover  ethics 
and control within TBC. TBC’s governance draws strength from its IFI shareholders. 
 
14. 
time chairperson and two members, one of which is an IFI-appointed supervisory board member. 
TBC’s Audit Department is staffed by experienced auditors and reports to the audit committee. 
Usual  observations  identify  and  help  address  (i)  fraud,  (ii)  system  deficiencies,  and  (iii) 
compliance  issues.  Audit  observations  have  not  identified  any  major  accounting,  operational, 
and  compliance  risks.  External  audit  assignments  are  carried  out  by  large  international  firms, 
with  TBC  currently  using  PricewaterhouseCoopers.  TBC’s  anti-money-laundering  unit  has  10 
staff  checking  transactions  above  GEL30,000.  The  anti-money-laundering  unit  identifies 
suspicious  transactions  by  scanning  information  by  source  of  wealth,  politically  exposed 
persons, and watch lists. It reports to the NBG Financial Investigation Unit.12

Terrorism.

The  proposed  objectives  of  the  loan  will  be  supported  by  technical  assistance  (TA) 
15. 
resources. First, resources will be made available to TBC under ADB’s ongoing TA for Capacity 
Building  for  Financial  Institutions,  Phase  2  to  improve  TBC’s  risk  management  and  lending 
practices,  including  its  business  expansion  to  rural  regions  within  Georgia.  13 Second,  ADB 
has—as  an  integral  part  of  its  support—approved  TA  for  NBG  to  support  the  review, 
improvement,  and  supervision  of  ICAAPs  across  Georgia’s  banking  system,  which  is  set  to 
commence  in  early  2013. 14  This  is  in  line  with  NBG’s  efforts  to  improve  financial  sector 
resilience.  Providing  lender-of-last-resort  facilities,  and  improving  asset  liability  management, 
including stress testing, are important focus areas to ensure adequate solvency and liquidity of 
banks.  ADB  has  been  supporting  NBG  since  2009  to  (i)  help  restructure  its  supervision 
department,  by  integrating  on-  and  off-site  supervision  through  a  group  approach  and 
establishing  a  systemic  risk  team;  (ii)  introduce  a  risk-based  approach  to  regulation  and 
supervision of financial institutions and incorporate macro-prudential and systemic risks; and (iii) 
strengthen its  risk  assessment  capabilities.  In  2011,  NBG  established a new  capital  adequacy 
regulation that complies with the Basel II and Basel III frameworks and requires banks’ gradual 
ICAAP implementation in 2013, forming the cornerstone for customized bank risk assessments 
and related capital requirements. While most of the banks are on track to comply with the new 
Basel II requirements, implementing the ICAAP under pillar 2 for the first time is challenging for 
banks and supervisors. 
 

III. 

THE PROPOSED ADB ASSISTANCE 

A. 

The Assistance 

The proposed ADB assistance consists of a senior loan facility of up to $50 million with a 
16. 
tenor  of  5  years.  The  proceeds  will  be  used  to  diversify  TBC’s  high  exposure  to  Tbilisi  by 
(i) increasing  lending  to  enterprises  exclusively  in  the  underserved  rural  regions;  (ii)  providing 
enhanced  access  to  longer-term  finance  for  the  MSME  segment,15 which  is  critical  to  support 
income  and  employment;  and  (iii)  gradually  funding  smaller  entities,  thereby  providing  greater 
diversification  of  TBC’s  loan  book,  and  reducing  TBC’s  exposure  to  its  large  borrowers  and 
groups.  The  senior  loan  will  be  available  to  TBC  for  onlending  to  MSMEs  sourced  through 
TBC’s retail, SMEs, and corporate platforms, as well as Bank Constanta’s microfinance lending 
platform.  The  proceeds  of  the  ADB  financing  will  be  exclusively  targeted  to  businesses 
operating in regions outside Tbilisi.  
 
B. 

Implementation Arrangements 

17. 
TBC will be required to provide annual audited financial statements in accordance with 
international  financial  reporting  standards.  TBC  will  also  provide  quarterly  financial  statements 
and compliance certificates for agreed covenants. Reporting requirements also include (i) status 
updates  for  introducing  and  maintaining  the  Basel  regulatory  framework;  (ii)  updates  on 
governance, safeguards, and social protection compliance; and (iii) updates on TBC’s business

performance  and  utilization  of  the  ADB  loan.  ADB  will  field  review  missions  semiannually  to

C. 

Value Added by ADB Assistance 

ADB  will  provide  stable  long-term  financing  which  currently  cannot  be  raised  from  the 
18. 
local  market.  Georgia’s  capital  markets  are  nascent,  and  public  confidence  in  the  financial 
sector  is  only  gradually  being  restored.  Commercial  bank  funding  is  also  not  readily  available 
given current market conditions in Europe. Finally, IFIs that are funding Georgian banks are now 
operating  within  tight  country  and  sector  exposure  limits—increasing  the  importance  of  ADB’s 
engagement. ADB will provide term financing and assist to build public confidence in the banks. 
 
19. 
Through close on-site monitoring and dialogue with TBC management, ADB will support 
TBC’s  adherence  to  high  corporate  governance  and  social,  environmental,  and  fiduciary 
standards, while enhancing standards for risk management. 
 
20. 
ADB has been responsive to the needs of TBC. Additional TA will be available for TBC 
under ADB’s ongoing TA for Capacity Building for Financial Institutions, Phase 2 (footnote 21). 
Through the semiannual consultation process between TBC and ADB, areas for deployment of 
TA  can  be  identified,  and  may  include  further  assistance  to  improve  risk  management  in  line 
with Basel II and III, and enhance TBC’s origination and monitoring standards for MSME clients 
using enhanced cash flow analysis.

IV. 

DEVELOPMENT IMPACT AND STRATEGIC ALIGNMENT 

A. 

Development Impact, Outcome, and Outputs 

Impact. The impacts of the investment are (i) improved access to financial services  for 
21. 
MSMEs,  and  (ii)  enhanced  resilience  of  Georgia’s  banking  system.  More  prudent  financial 
intermediation  by  banks  is  expected  to  lead  to  greater  consumer  confidence.  This  will  be 
reflected by an increase in bank deposits and loans, as well as an increase in the private credit 
to GDP ratio. 
 
22. 
Outcome. The outcome of the investment is that TBC remains profitable and becomes a 
more  resilient  bank,  prudently  serving  the  diverse  needs  of  Georgia’s  economy.  TBC  is 
expected  to  set  an  example  for  other  banks  in  the  industry  and  position  itself  to  be  able  to 
withstand  possible  future  financial  stress  by  putting  in  place  advanced  approaches  for 
maintaining  capital  adequacy,  improving  its  risk  management  capability  to  exceed  minimum 
requirements of Basel II, and improving efficiencies. 
 
23. 
Outputs.  The  output  of  the  investment  is  that  TBC  will  improve  its  service  outreach  to 
MSMEs, especially in the regions, and diversify its credit risk exposure by (i) reducing borrower, 
sector,  and  regional  concentration;  and  (ii)  ensuring  adequate  investment  is  made  in  human 
resources, processes, and systems. 

B. 

Alignment with ADB Strategy and Operations 

1. 

Consistency with Strategy 2020 and Country Strategy 

24. 
Under  Strategy  2020,  ADB  aims  to  strengthen  its  support  for  the  financial  sector  by 
supporting  the  development  of  financial  infrastructure,  institutions,  and  products  and  services, 

 

 

 

 and  by  promoting  inclusive  growth. 16 This  loan  will  help  TBC  to  reach  down  the  market  to 
MSMEs in rural regions and is consistent with the Government of Georgia’s efforts to invest in 
the  rural  regions,  particularly  in  the  areas  of  infrastructure,  agriculture,  and  agribusiness  after 
years of neglect that led to a concentration of activities in the capital. Strategy 2020’s target on 
poverty  reduction  through  private  sector  development  will  be  supported  via  TBC’s  new 
emphasis on activities outside the capital, where poverty is highest.

Consistency with Sector Strategy and Relevant ADB Operations 

26. 
Financial  sector  development  is  a  key  focus  of  ADB  assistance  as  set  out  in  ADB’s 
Private Sector Development Strategy18 and Enhanced Poverty Reduction Strategy,19 which note 
economic growth, stimulated by private sector investment, as a key factor in reducing poverty. 
These strategies  also  note  the  importance  of  generating  jobs,  with  private  sector  employment 
being  the  major  source  of  income  for  workers  and  their  families.  The  Private  Sector 
Development  Strategy  emphasizes  ADB’s  role  in  strengthening  the  financial  sectors  in  its 
developing member countries. It provides that SME beneficiaries of financial intermediation are 
important  employers  and  providers  of  income  to  contribute  to  poverty  reduction.  Support  of 
financial intermediaries is also important to instill confidence and restore the financial sector in 
crisis-hit  countries. The  loan is  consistent  with ADB’s  financial  sector  operational  plan and the 
2007 report of the Working Group on Rural Poverty,20 which underscores the importance of rural 
finance, and promotes financial inclusion of underserved poor households, farmers, and SMEs. 
 
ADB has approved three nonsovereign loans to banks in Georgia,  all of which targeted 
27. 
SMEs. 21 The  first  loan  to  BOG  was  made  immediately  after  Georgia  joined  ADB.  Although 
BOG’s  performance  was  adversely  affected  by  the  2008  crisis,  it  has  made  an  impressive 
recovery since 2010 and ADB’s loan has been repaid. ADB provided a second loan to BOG as 
a  response  to  the  2008  crisis,  which  was  critical  in  stabilizing  BOG’s  access  to  funding  and 
maintaining  its  outreach  to  SMEs.  While  higher  deposit  mobilization  and  international  capital 
market  resources  would  be  desirable,  public  confidence  in  banks  is  only  gradually  improving 
from low levels, and international investors remain risk averse given global economic conditions. 
As a result, IFI funding to solvent Georgian banks remains essential for Georgia’s transition to 
an inclusive financial system. Building on the previous interventions, the loan to TBC would take 
ADB’s financing downstream to MSMEs operating in the underserved rural regions.

A. 

Safeguards and Social Dimensions 

V. 

POLICY COMPLIANCE 

28. 
In  compliance  with  ADB’s  Safeguard  Policy  Statement,  the  senior  loan  is  classified 
category  FI  based  on  potential  impacts  on  the  environment,  and  category  FI  treated  as  C  for 
impacts  on  involuntary  resettlement  and  indigenous  peoples.  Subloans  under  environment 
category A, and social safeguards categories A and B will not be financed under the senior loan. 
The subloans’ potential environment and social impacts, its risks associated with TBC’s existing 
and  likely  future  portfolio,  and  TBC’s  commitment  and  capacity  for  environmental  and  social 
management, have been assessed. The existing environmental and social management system 
(ESMS)  established  by  TBC  and  the  agreed modifications  with  ADB  are  deemed  adequate  to 
comply  with  ADB’s  Safeguard  Policy  Statement.  TBC  will  ensure  that  investments  using  ADB 
funds  do  not  involve business  activities on  ADB’s  prohibited  investment activities list. TBC  will 
enhance  its  existing  ESMS  to  implement  the  modifications  agreed  with  ADB  before  the  first 
disbursement for subloan financing. The ESMS will include provisions requiring TBC to comply 
with  national  labor  laws  and  to  take  specific  measures  in  relation  to  the  internationally 
recognized core labor standards, in compliance with ADB’s social protection strategy.22 
 
B. 

Anticorruption Policy 

29. 
TBC was advised of ADB’s policy of implementing best international practice relating to 
combating  corruption,  money  laundering,  and  the  financing  of  terrorism.  ADB  will  ensure  that 
the  investment  documentation  includes  appropriate  provisions  prohibiting  corruption,  money 
laundering, and the financing of terrorism, and remedies for ADB in the event of noncompliance. 
 
C. 

Investment Limitations 

The proposed senior loan is within the medium-term country, industry, group, and single

will  enter  into  suitable  finance  documentation,  in  form  and  substance  satisfactory  to  ADB, 
following approval of the proposed assistance by the Board of Directors. 
 

VI. 

RECOMMENDATION 

 
32. 
I am satisfied that the proposed senior loan would comply with the Articles of Agreement 
of the Asian Development Bank (ADB) and recommend that the Board approve the senior loan 
of  $50,000,000  to  TBC  Bank  for  Promoting  Financial  Sector  Growth  and  Service  Diversity  in 
Georgia,  from  ADB’s  ordinary  capital  resources,  with  such  terms  and  conditions  as  are 
substantially  in  accordance  with  those  set  forth  in  this  report,  and  as  may  be  reported  to  the 
Board.
